de.esoco.lib.security

Class Security

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.security.Security

  • public class Security
extends java.lang.Object
    Contains static helper methods for typical security tasks like the creation of cryptographic certificates and keys and configuring Java security key stores and SSL contexts. Relies on the security relation types defined in SecurityRelationTypes.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static java.lang.String ALIAS_GENERATED_CERT
      A standard KeyStore alias for the certificate that has been created in a certificate creation request.
      static java.lang.String ALIAS_SERVER_CERT
      A standard KeyStore alias for a server certificate.
      static java.lang.String ALIAS_SIGNING_CERT
      A standard KeyStore alias for the signing certificate in a certificate creation request.

    • Method Detail

      • createKeyStore

        public static java.security.KeyStore createKeyStore(java.lang.String sAlias,
                                                    java.lang.String sPassword,
                                                    java.security.PrivateKey rPrivateKey,
                                                    java.security.cert.X509Certificate[] rCertChain)
        Creates a Java security key store containing a certain certificate chain and it's private key.
        Parameters:
        sAlias - The alias name for the certificate and key
        sPassword - The password for the private key
        rPrivateKey - The private key of the first certificate in the chain
        rCertChain - The certificate chain which must contain at least one certificate
        Returns:
        A new key store with the certificate chain and key
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If the certificate generation fails because of unavailable algorithms

      • decodeBase64

        public static byte[] decodeBase64(java.lang.String sBase64)
        decodes data that is encoded in base64 format, optionally in PEM format. The latter wraps the base64 data in uppercase begin and end tokens on separate lines describing the contained data enclosed in five dash characters on each side (e.g. '-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----' and '-----END CERTIFICATE-----') according to RFC 7468.
        Parameters:
        sBase64 - A string containing the Base64 encoded data
        Returns:
        The decoded binary data

      • decodeCertificate

        public static java.security.cert.X509Certificate decodeCertificate(byte[] rCertData)
        Reads an X509 certificate from an input stream.
        Parameters:
        rCertData - The input stream containing the certificate data
        Returns:
        The X509 certificate
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the certificate creation fails

      • decodePrivateKey

        public static java.security.PrivateKey decodePrivateKey(byte[] rPkcs8Key)
        Reads the binary data of a private key in PKCS8 format.
        Parameters:
        rPkcs8Key - An input stream providing the PKCS8 key data
        Returns:
        A new private key instance
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the key cannot be created from the input

      • decrypt

        public static java.lang.String decrypt(byte[] rData,
                                       java.lang.String sPassphrase)
        Decrypts a string value with the given passphrase by using the AES algorithm. The passphrase will be converted into a 128 bit AES key by applying the method deriveKey(String, String, int).
        Parameters:
        rData - The data to decrypt
        sPassphrase - The passphrase
        Returns:
        The decrypted data

      • deriveKey

        public static java.security.Key deriveKey(java.lang.String sPassphrase,
                                          java.lang.String sAlgorithm,
                                          int nBitLength)
        Derives an cryptographic key with a certain length from a passphrase. The key will be generated as a SHA-256 hash of the passphrase which will then be reduced to the requested bit length.
        Parameters:
        sPassphrase - The passphrase
        sAlgorithm - The algorithm of the returned key
        nBitLength - The bit length of the returned key
        Returns:
        The resulting key
        Throws:
        java.lang.SecurityException - If deriving the key fails

      • enableJavaCryptographicExtensions

        public static void enableJavaCryptographicExtensions()
        This method will enable java cryptographic extensions on the application level if possible.

        Attention: this performs a rather dirty hack by using reflection to set a field in the class 'javax.crypto.JceSecurity' to FALSE. That is necessary because otherwise some JCE security algorithms are not availabe. Whether or not this actually works depends on the platform that the application is deployed to and its JRE. Keep an eye out for logged errors that might occur at application startup/initialization of this endpoint.

      • encodeBase64

        public static java.lang.String encodeBase64(byte[] rData,
                                            java.lang.String sToken)
        Encodes binary cryptographic data into base64 in PEM format according to RFC 7468.
        Parameters:
        rData - The binary data to encode
        sToken - The token for the PEM delimiters describing the encoded data (will be converted to uppercase)
        Returns:
        An ASCII string containing the encoded data

      • encrypt

        public static byte[] encrypt(java.lang.String sValue,
                             java.lang.String sPassphrase)
        Encrypts a string value with the given passphrase by using the AES algorithm. The passphrase will be converted into a 128 bit AES key by applying the method deriveKey(String, String, int).
        Parameters:
        sValue - The value to encrypt
        sPassphrase - The passphrase
        Returns:
        The encrypted data

      • generateHashId

        public static java.lang.String generateHashId(java.lang.String sAlgorithm)
        Generates a random ID based by applying a certain hash algorithm. This is done by hashing a random UUID (see UUID.randomUUID()) and returning the resulting hash as a hexadecimal string with the length of the algorithms hash size (e.g. 32 bytes for the SHA-256 algorithm).
        Parameters:
        sAlgorithm - The name of the hash algorithm to apply
        Returns:
        The random hash ID
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the hash algorithm cannot be found

      • generateKeyPair

        public static java.security.KeyPair generateKeyPair(java.lang.String sAlgorithm,
                                                    int nKeySize)
        Generates a key pair with the given algorithm and key size.
        Parameters:
        sAlgorithm - The algorithm name as defined in the Java cryptography packages
        nKeySize - The number of bits in the key
        Returns:
        The generated key pair
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the given algorithm could not be found (mapped from NoSuchAlgorithmException)

      • generateSha256Id

        public static java.lang.String generateSha256Id()
        Generates a random ID based on the SHA-256 hash algorithm. This is done by hashing a random UUID (see UUID.randomUUID()) and returning the resulting hash as a hexadecimal string with 32 characters (= 256 bits).
        Returns:
        The random SHA-256 ID

      • getSslContext

        public static javax.net.ssl.SSLContext getSslContext(java.security.KeyStore rKeyStore,
                                                     java.lang.String sKeyStorePassword)
        Initializes an SSL context from a key store so that it will use the certificates from the key store for SSL/TLS connections.
        Parameters:
        rKeyStore - The key store to initialize the context from
        sKeyStorePassword - The key store password
        Returns:
        A new SSL context initialized to use the given key store
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the parameters are invalid or refer to unavailable security algorithms
